awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Defects and Dopants in Critical Wide Band Gap Semiconductors - ZnO, InGaZnO, Ga2O3 and ScN
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: The project explores the electronic and chemical properties of atomic-scale imperfections in the semiconductors zinc oxide, gallium oxide, indium gallium oxide, and scandium nitride with a specific focus on controlling such defects for higher power, speed, and light output of advanced electronic devices. Such defects may degrade semiconductor properties by trapping charge carriers to reduce the current and charge speed. These imperfections depend sensitively on the specific techniques used for growing and/or subsequent thermal, chemical, and plasma treatments. The research, which combines experimental studies with transport modeling, is aimed at measuring the optical properties of lattice structural and chemical imperfections of these relatively unexplored semiconductors, using growth variations, plasma, hydrogen annealing, and irradiation treatments to identify their physical nature and electrical measurements in magnetic fields to identify their ability to donate or accept electrons. The project ultimate goal is to understand the nature of these defects and eventually to eliminate them. The ability to remove these structural and/or chemical defects impacts a range of technologies. Zinc oxide is a prime candidate to replace today's high-cost materials in solar cells, digital displays, and light emitting diodes. Gallium oxide's ability to handle very high voltages can improve power switches for telecommunications and power transmission. Indium gallium oxide can provide higher speed displays and high-resolution TVs. Scandium nitride can lower resistance and power consumption of metallic contacts to semiconductors used in cellphones. The activities provide collaborative research opportunities for a graduate student, several university undergraduates, and high school students from an all-girl's high school.

Technical description: The research focuses on fundamental studies of native point defects in the semiconductors ZnO, Ga2O3, InGaZnO, and ScN, which have emerged as critical materials for advanced high power and optoelectronic display applications. ZnO, doped with Ga or Al, is the prime candidate to replace expensive indium tin oxide in solar cells, displays, light emitting diodes, and touchscreens. Ga2O3 is the dominant new material for power switches because of its record high breakdown voltage. InGaZnO is the dominant amorphous oxide replacing amorphous-Si transistors in displays and high-resolution TVs (e.g., Sharp). ScN can improve ohmic contacts in GaN-based devices and serve as a buffer layer for GaN-on-Si technology. All four can be highly doped with impurity donors, yet all four are impacted by deep level defects that compensate free carriers and introduce scattering that reduces carrier mobility. The nature of native point defects in Ga2O3, InGaZnO, and ScN as well as ZnO is almost completely unexplored, yet these defects can have a major impact on carrier density, mobility, and interface transport. The research team will measure the spatial distribution and physical nature of specific defects using 3-dimensional nanoscale optical spectroscopies coupled with donor /acceptor densities and dielectric properties by temperature-dependent Hall effect and reflectance/transmission measurements, respectively, in order to identify and quantify defect densities on a near-nm scale and understand how to control them through new growth and processing techniques. The goals of this work are to understand the primary compensating defects in these compounds that limit degenerate doping and produce lower mobilities, combining near-surface remote plasma, implantation and thermal processing with optical and surface science techniques to identify these native point defects, correlate them with donor/acceptor densities, and chemically control them. The project also aims to explore the impact of these defects on barriers and transport at Schottky barriers and heterojunctions involving these semiconductors. The overall goal of the project is to control these defects and their impact on carrier densities and junction transport by selected growth and processing techniques that improve conductivity and interface properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the nature of native point defects in zinc oxide (ZnO), gallium oxide (Ga2O3), indium gallium zinc oxide (InGaZnO), and scandium nitride (ScN) as well as both ZnO and Ga2O3 nanowires and how they impact free carrier density, mobility, and interface charge transport. It identified the densities, spatial distributions, and physical nature of multiple point defects inside ZnO nanowires, measuring their variation radially and lengthwise for tapered wires and showing how these defects can now be manipulated by ion beam methods and nanowire design. This opens new avenues to control nanowire charge injection and transport. A combination of electron microscopy, spectroscopic, electrostatic and structural techniques revealed optical signatures of mid-gap states associated with cation sublattice disorder in zinc gallium nitride (ZnGaN2), emphasizing how growth and processing conditions control cation place exchange. ScN single crystals with high electron mobility and high thermal conductivity grown by physical vapor transport (PVT) exhibited thermal conductivity three times higher than those in reported previously, demonstrating the viability of the PVT crystal growth method for producing high quality bulk ScN single crystals. Depth-resolved cathodoluminescence spectroscopy (DRCLS) provided optical signatures of both the mid-gap nitrogen vacancy precursor to oxygen on nitrogen site doping as well as the optical energies corresponding to four different conduction band-to-valence band transitions, in agreement with theory. While thin film ScN grown by reactive magnetron sputtering displayed degenerate doping by substitutional oxygen, ScN grown by physical vapor transport exhibited the intrinsic, non-degenerate, lowest bandgap predicted by theory. DRCLS and X-ray photoemission spectroscopy identified sub- bandgap emission with nitrogen vacancies, in strong agreement with theoretical calculations. Quantum magnetoconductivity (QMC) in zinc gallate (ZnGa2O4) thin films grown by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition on sapphire reveal phonon contributions to electron mobility that can be directly measured over a wide temperature span. An analytical formula for mobility yields an effective phonon energy that account for all phonon contributions at a given temperature. The total measured mobility can then be modeled to extract mobility due to ionized-impurity scattering. DRCLS of strontium titanate (SrTiO3) revealed sub-band gap luminescence whose spectral fine structures were in excellent agreement with theoretically-predicted optical transitions from intrinsic point defects including titanium on strontium crystal lattice sites. Together with growth control of specific defect densities, this approach allows for more reliable, self-consistent defect studies and provides critical insight into a microscopic picture of complex oxide point defects. DRCLS measured the electronic structure of vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) in excellent agreement with theory, also measuring the changes inside these films with lithiation on a near-nanometer scale.  This capability can help inform solid state battery designs to withstand degradation and increase efficiency. DRCLS combined with Raman spectroscopy revealed changes in lithiated V2O5 electronic structure from the surface to the bulk of battery cathode thin films showing that its electrochemical performance degradation with deep discharge is associated with drastic band structure changes that accompany octahedral distortion, rather than a chemical conversion reaction. A review of advances in measuring native point defects in nanostructures showed how these defects affect nanoscale electronic properties and showing how new techniques to manipulate these defects can control nano- and micro-wire electronic properties. These defects within nanowires and metal interfaces can dominate electrical contact properties, yet are sensitive to manipulation by chemical interactions, energy beams, and applied electric fields. The ability to measure and manipulate these native point defects presents exciting possibilities for future ZnO nanoscale electronics. These advances suggest new methods to achieve rectifying ZnO nanowire contacts for wearable electronics and flexible displays, methods to grow ScN single crystals with high electron mobility and thermal conductivity for optoelectronic, piezoelectronic, spintronic, and thermoelectric applications, methods to grow controllable conductivity, high breakdown voltage, bulk zinc gallate for high-power electronics and ultraviolet detectors, and longer life passivated solid-state battery cathodes. In addition to these advances, this project also made available to the research community the QMC method of studying phonons in degenerate semiconductors that can be used to measure directly the inelastic phonon scattering rate contributions to electron mobility over the temperature range from ten to two hundred degrees Kelvin. Total measured mobility due to both phonons plus ionized-impurity scattering can then be modeled from an approximate analytical formula, leading to a quantitative measure of interface disorder that can be used to characterize interfaces for any degenerate semiconductor film on any semi-insulating substrate.
